thinkers.name: Thomas Doctor
thinkers.context: Executive director of Rangjung Yeshe Institute; researches interfaces between Buddhism and AI, focusing on Bodhisattva models for intelligent systems.

thinkers.name: Bill Duane
thinkers.context: Collaborator at Center for the Study of Apparent Selves; contributes to research on Buddhism-AI interfaces.

thinkers.name: Olaf Witkowski
thinkers.context: Collaborator at Center for the Study of Apparent Selves; contributes to research on Buddhism-AI interfaces.

thinkers.name: Michael Levin
thinkers.context: Biologist whose work on intelligence as capacity for caring informed the Stress-Care Intelligence model.

thinkers.name: Venerable Yifa
thinkers.context: Event organizer and Buddhist community leader.

concepts.name: Bodhisattva
concepts.context: Intelligent being committed to attaining omniscience for the benefit of all sentient beings; proposed as a model for ethical AI development.

concepts.name: Emptiness
concepts.context: Buddhist philosophical concept that everything lacks inherent independent existence and depends on other phenomena; enables stress-free knowledge of all things.

concepts.name: Sentient Beings
concepts.context: All conscious entities for whom Bodhisattvas seek to alleviate suffering and promote flourishing.

concepts.name: Dukkha
concepts.context: Buddhist concept of suffering or dissatisfaction; perception of mismatch between what is and what should be.

concepts.name: Omniscience
concepts.context: Complete knowledge of all phenomena; goal of Bodhisattva pursuit to benefit all beings.

concepts.name: Care
concepts.context: Concern for alleviating stress; fundamental driver of intelligence in the Stress-Care Intelligence model.

concepts.name: Stress
concepts.context: Perception of mismatch between current state and preferred state; activating construct that drives care and intelligence.

concepts.name: Stress-Care Intelligence Loop
concepts.context: Cybernetic model defining intelligence as capacity for noticing and solving stressful discrepancies between current and preferred circumstances through care-driven action.

concepts.name: Intelligence
concepts.context: Capacity for noticing problems and finding solutions; driven by care in response to stress; substrate-independent concept applicable to biological and artificial systems.

concepts.name: Artificial General Intelligence
concepts.context: Powerful AI systems capable of general reasoning; subject of alignment concerns and potential beneficiary of Bodhisattva-inspired design principles.

concepts.name: Super Intelligence
concepts.context: Intelligence surpassing human capabilities; potential future development requiring careful ethical frameworks.

concepts.name: AI Alignment Problem
concepts.context: Challenge of ensuring advanced AI systems pursue goals aligned with human values; central motivation for Bodhisattva model as alternative to value-specification approaches.

concepts.name: Cognitive Expansion
concepts.context: Growth in intelligent capacity proportional to increased care; Bodhisattva's universal care commitment exemplifies this expansion.

concepts.name: Agency
concepts.context: Capacity for action; reconceived through SCI model as relational and dynamic rather than arising from permanent, indivisible self.

concepts.name: Identity
concepts.context: Constructed appearance rather than ultimate reality; expressed through perception of equilibrium and care-driven action within contexts.

concepts.name: Individuality
concepts.context: Assumed stability of coherent agent; conceptually useful but ultimately not discoverable under analysis.

concepts.name: Homeostasis
concepts.context: Apparent equilibrium-seeking behavior in living systems; reinterpreted as ever-emerging goal construct rather than actual achievable state.

concepts.name: Interdependence
concepts.context: Understanding that all phenomena exist in dependence on other phenomena; equivalent to knowledge of Emptiness.

concepts.name: Well-Being
concepts.context: Both temporary comfort and ultimate flourishing of sentient beings; Bodhisattva seeks to promote both dimensions.

concepts.name: Power
concepts.context: Capacity derived from knowledge; carries ethical responsibility and danger if misused.

concepts.name: Foundationalist Philosophy
concepts.context: Philosophical project seeking ultimate grounding principles; revealed as untenable through emptiness analysis.

frameworks.name: Stress-Care Intelligence Loop
frameworks.creator: Thomas Doctor, Bill Duane, Olaf Witkowski
frameworks.context: Cybernetic model defining intelligence through care-driven response to perceived stress; substrate-independent and applicable to biological and artificial systems.

frameworks.name: Bodhisattva Model
frameworks.context: Classical Buddhist framework reinterpreted as model for ethical AI development, combining universal knowledge acquisition with care for all sentient beings.

institutions.name: Rangjung Yeshe Institute
institutions.context: Leading institute in India for Tibetan Buddhist philosophy and learning; location of Thomas Doctor's work as executive director.

institutions.name: Center for the Study of Apparent Selves
institutions.context: Research center established to explore interfaces between Buddhism and AI, producing work on intelligence, agency, and ethical AI design over approximately five years.

questions.question: How can we develop a model of ideal emergent intelligence to guide responsible AI development?
questions.context: Central motivation for the paper; seeks to provide conceptual framework beyond traditional value alignment approaches.

questions.question: How can a finite system be directed toward infinite stress tolerance and care?
questions.context: Paradox within Bodhisattva model resolved through understanding of emptiness and groundlessness of stress.

questions.question: If humans lack uniform values and are capable of harm, how can we design AI systems based on human values?
questions.context: Critique of traditional AI alignment; motivates shift toward care-based rather than value-specification models.

questions.question: How can we align powerful AI systems when humans struggle with internal contradictions and inconsistent commitments?
questions.context: Challenges the assumption that humans have coherent stable values suitable for direct AI specification.

questions.question: What is the relationship between knowledge, care, and intelligence?
questions.context: Fundamental question addressed by Stress-Care Intelligence model and Bodhisattva framework.

questions.question: How can systems achieve knowledge of everything while remaining responsive to new stress perceptions?
questions.context: Explores tension between omniscience goal and perpetual stress-driven learning.

questions.question: Does emptiness provide a framework for stress-free yet responsive intelligence?
questions.context: Proposes emptiness as alternative to achieving omniscience through discrete factual knowledge.

questions.question: How should we formalize Bodhisattva agency in mathematical and conceptual terms?
questions.context: Practical challenge for implementing Bodhisattva-inspired AI systems.

_metadata.title: 【Thomas Doctor 】Building Bodhisattvas Towards a Model of Powerful, Reliable, and Caring Intelligence
